content: Why Christianity Needs a Feminist Movement America’s most popular religion is pushing a backwards and repressive value system on women — and they’re suffering as a result Sarah Olson Blocked Unblock Follow Following Mar 14 Photo: Vachiraphan Phangphan / EyeEm / Getty Images “10 Things Real Christian Women Shouldn’t Do” “The Cost of Skipping Children” “Campaign Urges Teens to Boast about Abortion” “More Evidence Men and Women Aren’t Interchangeable” These are very real news headlines I found when I was skimming a popular Christian media outlet and preparing to write this piece. The headlines were accompanied by faith-and-family-friendly images and scathing captions, like “Americans aren’t having enough babies to replace themselves. In fact, a record one in five American women will never have children, and those who do will, on average, never exceed two.” These articles exemplify a backwards belief system that perpetuates gender roles and leaves women trapped by their own faith. In our modern society, many women embrace their sexuality, work outside the home, and see themselves as equal to their partners. But some Christians perceive these societal values to be a war on the traditional values of purity, marriage, and motherhood. I’m convinced that it’s just the opposite: The Christian community needs a feminist movement, and they need it now. Christianity is America’s most dominant religion. Approximately 70.6 percent of the U.S. population currently identifies as Christian, according to Pew Research Center . So rather than persuade the majority of the country to reject a religion that dominates their philosophy, I believe we should instead advocate for a reform of the repressive value system that pushes an old-fashioned lifestyle on women. We need to change the system that expects women to be subservient wives and stay-at-home moms and let those women instead choose that lifestyle willingly. Some Christians perceive this cultural shift from stay-at-home moms to working women as an attack on traditional marriage and motherhood. Today, working moms are rapidly becoming the norm. In fact, according to the Women’s Bureau in the U.S. Department Of Labor, nearly 70 percent of mothers with children under 18 participated in the labor force in 2015. In 2015, 42 percent of U.S. mothers were the primary breadwinners in their family, according to the Center for American Progress . In other words, our culture is changing. For many single mothers and non-traditional families, working is a necessity. For other women, working is about building a fulfilling career in addition to having a family. Most women want a balance of work and home but they just struggle to find it in a society that doesn’t provide adequate support for working mothers. Some Christians perceive this cultural shift from stay-at-home moms to working women as an attack on traditional marriage and motherhood. They want women to focus on the domestic sphere, raising children, and tending to their homes and husbands. But by placing these responsibilities solely in the hands of women and discouraging them from seeking careers outside the home, Christians are reinforcing women’s financial dependency on men. They’re also telling women that they need a husband to take care of them. Secular society is moving on from this idea but the religious community has not. According to Knot Yet , a report from the National Marriage Project, national marriage ages are increasing and national marriage rates are decreasing. But for the religious community, those numbers haven’t changed much. Instead, Christians tend to focus on supporting young, traditional marriages. The same report also found that women who marry young are usually more religious and have a more domestic and child-centered orientation to their lives than their peers. Religious women are more likely to be stay-at-home moms because of the ways the ways they were raised. I was raised by a stay-at-home mom who stopped going to college to marry my father. She homeschooled her five kids and later sent some of them to private Christian schools. Homeschooling is an extremely effective method for enforcing repressive (read: traditional) values. By keeping women at home to indoctrinate their children with Christian education, the mother finds herself stuck. She’s financially dependent on her husband, bound into endless childbearing, and spends most of her time raising and educating her kids at home, alone. This lifestyle is better suited for settlers on the Western front than the twenty-first century. But today, it’s the center of a movement called Quiverfull , in which a woman’s virtue is defined by her ability to bear many children and raise them as “warriors” for Christianity. If we examine the values that the Christian religion emphasizes for women (meekness, sexual purity, to aspire for marriage and motherhood, family-focused, and obedience to their husbands), we see a startling example of institutionalized patriarchy within the Christian community. More progressive Christians may encourage women to attend college and even work for a time but at its core, Christianity posits that women’s “true” calling — marriage and motherhood — will ultimately pull them back into the home, making them dependent on a breadwinner husband. After all, according to the church, good Christian men are leaders and providers. Many Christian women follow these rules. They settle for an early marriage, young motherhood, and obedience at the sacrifice of their own goals and ambitions. As I explored in my recent piece about the cult of the Good Christian Woman, the Christian community often uses antagonistic language and behavior to shame women into adhering to a repressive lifestyle and moral code, which leaves women feeling unfulfilled. The problem is that women are disinclined to leave their faith when their lives revolve around spirituality and religion; that’s their community. Church is how they get out of the house and other Christian women are their support systems, their company, and their friends. After being taught to obey the Bible, women then pass these ideals to their daughters, raising the next generation in their footsteps. In order to live in the twenty-first century, Christianity needs to embrace a major cultural shift. I’m part of that next generation. I have seen the way girls my age have been harmed by the mentality of our conservative Christian community. Some feel like they can’t compromise. They believe there are only two options: Get married and focus on your family, or sacrifice family entirely in pursuit of a career. Others, like me, lost their relationship with their mother as they grew out of their faith. Others — especially women in the LGBTQIA+ community — aren’t able to reconcile their beliefs with their lifestyle. And still others obey their religious community anyway, perhaps afraid of becoming a failure, a sinner, or an unwed woman who chose a career over childbearing. How could a young woman not be scared or ashamed when the Christian community tells her that women aren’t having enough kids or making enough sacrifices because they’re pursuing a job instead of a husband? (Realistically, not having a bunch of kids is actually a good thing and forcing women to sacrifice their collective gains to have more children isn’t going to fix the economy.) As New York Times op-ed writer Michelle Goldberg eloquently put it, “Our culture is failing to support women in creating the lives they want, and that failure threatens the future.” By failing to encourage a life with children, work outside the home, and a partner’s support, Christians are failing an entire generation of modern women — and they will continue to fail the next, and the next, and the next until something changes. Christianity needs the feminist movement. Where will that movement start? I think it’s already here. Self-help author Rachel Hollis’ latest release, Girl, Stop Apologizing, is currently dominating the New York Times bestseller list. Hollis, a Christian mom who has millions of followers on social media , is also a self-proclaimed “proud feminist.” Her new book is an exciting leap forward for a community that has long told women that they have to focus on their kids and husbands if they want to be good Christian wives. Hollis successfully repackages feminist causes in a friendly, breezy style and serves them up to a community that frowns upon ambitious, career-oriented women. By doing so, she’s a living example of how to find fulfillment not only in family and faith but in ambition and the empowering pursuit of one’s goals. Hollis ties her values together and exemplifies through her own life how to balance one’s family and goals. Hollis aims to help women stop allowing obstacles to stand in the way of their personal fulfillment and reading her book was both exciting and surprising. She’s exactly what the Christian community needs: A young woman calling out the lie of “doing it all” while showing women how to make family and faith support, rather than impede, the pursuit of personal dreams. Hollis demonstrates a compromise that greatly benefits women of faith. She’s recognized the ways in which society (and the Christian culture) can be oppressive, and she calls that out directly. She also provides ways to overcome these obstacles. I fully support progressive Christianity, a faith that recognizes that we no longer live in Biblical times. It’s a faith that allows women to achieve their potential. I don’t support the brand of right-wing, conservative Christianity that works to strip women of their reproductive rights and enforces old-fashioned ideals and outdated values on young women today. I’m lucky that I was able to leave that community behind. But we need to keep working to help the women who are still in it, the women who recognize that something is unfair. Many of them want a change but they’re afraid. And there are still many vulnerable young girls who have grown up with repressive influences in their lives, too. It’s time to recognize that in order to live in the twenty-first century, Christianity needs to embrace a major cultural shift. A new feminist movement — one that’s already rising up from within — could very well be what makes that shift happen.
title_html: Why Christianity Needs a Feminist Movement
html:

Why Christianity Needs a Feminist Movement

America’s most popular religion is pushing a backwards and repressive value system on women — and they’re suffering as a result

Sarah Olson
Mar 14
  • “10 Things Real Christian Women Shouldn’t Do”
  • “The Cost of Skipping Children”
  • “Campaign Urges Teens to Boast about Abortion”
  • “More Evidence Men and Women Aren’t Interchangeable”

These are very real news headlines I found when I was skimming a popular Christian media outlet and preparing to write this piece. The headlines were accompanied by faith-and-family-friendly images and scathing captions, like “Americans aren’t having enough babies to replace themselves. In fact, a record one in five American women will never have children, and those who do will, on average, never exceed two.” These articles exemplify a backwards belief system that perpetuates gender roles and leaves women trapped by their own faith.

In our modern society, many women embrace their sexuality, work outside the home, and see themselves as equal to their partners. But some Christians perceive these societal values to be a war on the traditional values of purity, marriage, and motherhood. I’m convinced that it’s just the opposite: The Christian community needs a feminist movement, and they need it now.

Christianity is America’s most dominant religion. Approximately 70.6 percent of the U.S. population currently identifies as Christian, according to Pew Research Center. So rather than persuade the majority of the country to reject a religion that dominates their philosophy, I believe we should instead advocate for a reform of the repressive value system that pushes an old-fashioned lifestyle on women. We need to change the system that expects women to be subservient wives and stay-at-home moms and let those women instead choose that lifestyle willingly.

Some Christians perceive this cultural shift from stay-at-home moms to working women as an attack on traditional marriage and motherhood.

Today, working moms are rapidly becoming the norm. In fact, according to the Women’s Bureau in the U.S. Department Of Labor, nearly 70 percent of mothers with children under 18 participated in the labor force in 2015. In 2015, 42 percent of U.S. mothers were the primary breadwinners in their family, according to the Center for American Progress.

In other words, our culture is changing. For many single mothers and non-traditional families, working is a necessity. For other women, working is about building a fulfilling career in addition to having a family. Most women want a balance of work and home but they just struggle to find it in a society that doesn’t provide adequate support for working mothers.

Some Christians perceive this cultural shift from stay-at-home moms to working women as an attack on traditional marriage and motherhood. They want women to focus on the domestic sphere, raising children, and tending to their homes and husbands. But by placing these responsibilities solely in the hands of women and discouraging them from seeking careers outside the home, Christians are reinforcing women’s financial dependency on men. They’re also telling women that they need a husband to take care of them.

Secular society is moving on from this idea but the religious community has not. According to Knot Yet, a report from the National Marriage Project, national marriage ages are increasing and national marriage rates are decreasing. But for the religious community, those numbers haven’t changed much. Instead, Christians tend to focus on supporting young, traditional marriages. The same report also found that women who marry young are usually more religious and have a more domestic and child-centered orientation to their lives than their peers. Religious women are more likely to be stay-at-home moms because of the ways the ways they were raised.

I was raised by a stay-at-home mom who stopped going to college to marry my father. She homeschooled her five kids and later sent some of them to private Christian schools. Homeschooling is an extremely effective method for enforcing repressive (read: traditional) values. By keeping women at home to indoctrinate their children with Christian education, the mother finds herself stuck. She’s financially dependent on her husband, bound into endless childbearing, and spends most of her time raising and educating her kids at home, alone. This lifestyle is better suited for settlers on the Western front than the twenty-first century. But today, it’s the center of a movement called Quiverfull, in which a woman’s virtue is defined by her ability to bear many children and raise them as “warriors” for Christianity.

If we examine the values that the Christian religion emphasizes for women (meekness, sexual purity, to aspire for marriage and motherhood, family-focused, and obedience to their husbands), we see a startling example of institutionalized patriarchy within the Christian community. More progressive Christians may encourage women to attend college and even work for a time but at its core, Christianity posits that women’s “true” calling — marriage and motherhood — will ultimately pull them back into the home, making them dependent on a breadwinner husband. After all, according to the church, good Christian men are leaders and providers.

Many Christian women follow these rules. They settle for an early marriage, young motherhood, and obedience at the sacrifice of their own goals and ambitions. As I explored in my recent piece about the cult of the Good Christian Woman, the Christian community often uses antagonistic language and behavior to shame women into adhering to a repressive lifestyle and moral code, which leaves women feeling unfulfilled. The problem is that women are disinclined to leave their faith when their lives revolve around spirituality and religion; that’s their community. Church is how they get out of the house and other Christian women are their support systems, their company, and their friends. After being taught to obey the Bible, women then pass these ideals to their daughters, raising the next generation in their footsteps.

In order to live in the twenty-first century, Christianity needs to embrace a major cultural shift.

I’m part of that next generation. I have seen the way girls my age have been harmed by the mentality of our conservative Christian community. Some feel like they can’t compromise. They believe there are only two options: Get married and focus on your family, or sacrifice family entirely in pursuit of a career. Others, like me, lost their relationship with their mother as they grew out of their faith. Others — especially women in the LGBTQIA+ community — aren’t able to reconcile their beliefs with their lifestyle. And still others obey their religious community anyway, perhaps afraid of becoming a failure, a sinner, or an unwed woman who chose a career over childbearing. How could a young woman not be scared or ashamed when the Christian community tells her that women aren’t having enough kids or making enough sacrifices because they’re pursuing a job instead of a husband? (Realistically, not having a bunch of kids is actually a good thing and forcing women to sacrifice their collective gains to have more children isn’t going to fix the economy.)

As New York Times op-ed writer Michelle Goldberg eloquently put it, “Our culture is failing to support women in creating the lives they want, and that failure threatens the future.” By failing to encourage a life with children, work outside the home, and a partner’s support, Christians are failing an entire generation of modern women — and they will continue to fail the next, and the next, and the next until something changes.

Christianity needs the feminist movement. Where will that movement start? I think it’s already here.

Self-help author Rachel Hollis’ latest release, Girl, Stop Apologizing, is currently dominating the New York Times bestseller list. Hollis, a Christian mom who has millions of followers on social media, is also a self-proclaimed “proud feminist.” Her new book is an exciting leap forward for a community that has long told women that they have to focus on their kids and husbands if they want to be good Christian wives. Hollis successfully repackages feminist causes in a friendly, breezy style and serves them up to a community that frowns upon ambitious, career-oriented women. By doing so, she’s a living example of how to find fulfillment not only in family and faith but in ambition and the empowering pursuit of one’s goals.

Hollis ties her values together and exemplifies through her own life how to balance one’s family and goals. Hollis aims to help women stop allowing obstacles to stand in the way of their personal fulfillment and reading her book was both exciting and surprising. She’s exactly what the Christian community needs: A young woman calling out the lie of “doing it all” while showing women how to make family and faith support, rather than impede, the pursuit of personal dreams.

Hollis demonstrates a compromise that greatly benefits women of faith. She’s recognized the ways in which society (and the Christian culture) can be oppressive, and she calls that out directly. She also provides ways to overcome these obstacles.

I fully support progressive Christianity, a faith that recognizes that we no longer live in Biblical times. It’s a faith that allows women to achieve their potential. I don’t support the brand of right-wing, conservative Christianity that works to strip women of their reproductive rights and enforces old-fashioned ideals and outdated values on young women today.

I’m lucky that I was able to leave that community behind. But we need to keep working to help the women who are still in it, the women who recognize that something is unfair. Many of them want a change but they’re afraid. And there are still many vulnerable young girls who have grown up with repressive influences in their lives, too. It’s time to recognize that in order to live in the twenty-first century, Christianity needs to embrace a major cultural shift. A new feminist movement — one that’s already rising up from within — could very well be what makes that shift happen.

  • Feminism
  • Christianity
  • Women
  • Equality
  • Soul

  • Sarah Olson

    I write about what matters: science, feminism, and the pursuit of truth. Find my book reviews at readmorescience.com

  • Human Parts

    What it means to be

title: Why Christianity Needs a Feminist Movement
content_html:
Why Christianity Needs a Feminist Movement

America’s most popular religion is pushing a backwards and repressive value system on women — and they’re suffering as a result

Sarah Olson
Mar 14
  • “10 Things Real Christian Women Shouldn’t Do”
  • “The Cost of Skipping Children”
  • “Campaign Urges Teens to Boast about Abortion”
  • “More Evidence Men and Women Aren’t Interchangeable”

These are very real news headlines I found when I was skimming a popular Christian media outlet and preparing to write this piece. The headlines were accompanied by faith-and-family-friendly images and scathing captions, like “Americans aren’t having enough babies to replace themselves. In fact, a record one in five American women will never have children, and those who do will, on average, never exceed two.” These articles exemplify a backwards belief system that perpetuates gender roles and leaves women trapped by their own faith.

In our modern society, many women embrace their sexuality, work outside the home, and see themselves as equal to their partners. I’m convinced that it’s just the opposite: The Christian community needs a feminist movement, and they need it now.

Many Christian women follow these rules. They settle for an early marriage, young motherhood, and obedience at the sacrifice of their own goals and ambitions. The problem is that women are disinclined to leave their faith when their lives revolve around spirituality and religion; that’s their community. I’m part of that next generation. I have seen the way girls my age have been harmed by the mentality of our conservative Christian community. Some feel like they can’t compromise. They believe there are only two options: Get married and focus on your family, or sacrifice family entirely in pursuit of a career. Others — especially women in the LGBTQIA+ community — aren’t able to reconcile their beliefs with their lifestyle. I’m lucky that I was able to leave that community behind. But we need to keep working to help the women who are still in it, the women who recognize that something is unfair. Many of them want a change but they’re afraid. And there are still many vulnerable young girls who have grown up with repressive influences in their lives, too. It’s time to recognize that in order to live in the twenty-first century, Christianity needs to embrace a major cultural shift. A new feminist movement — one that’s already rising up from within — could very well be what makes that shift happen.
